title: If the UK participates in European Parliament elections, what percentage of votes will the Brexit Party win?
preds: Based upon my personal interactions with the MEP candidates for East Anglia and the British Election Study by the University of Essex
Going with recent comments made by Nigster and Emil referencing g current polling results

Polls bias liberal.
People are motivated.
I would go all in, however Boris Johnson's entrance into the race isn't properly accounted for in the polls. Boris's personal popularity will shift some to the Tories.
Update taking into account latest polls.

Two latest polls place the Brexit Party above 35% [1] [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls Edit: seems like the median of the crowd got a score of 0.0. Maybe good to know @amory10

An average of the 7 most recent polls weighted by sample size puts the Brexit Party on 35.0%. Recent polls: 35%*, 34%, 31%, 34%*, 30%, 38%, 37% * Large sample size. Crowd: 12%, 16%, 23%, 31%, 18% https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls

It's going to be high. Likely to rock establishment. MSM already recognises this, hence throwing the 'PayPal' and 'Who funds Farage?' bombs into the mix as early as possible.  They've looked at the numbers, they know what's coming. Remain will have a strong showing, but confusion between LibDem and Lab position, i.e. who is most clearly remain and how to act effectively will  make it difficult to read the numbers. Milkshakes and Remainer conspiracy only make Brexit party stronger and look more legitimate.
UK and EU are like a broten couple.

Noteworthy data: ComRes pollster outlet, which previously gave the Brexit Party 27-28% in three consecutive polls now gives it 32% in latest, relatively large poll [1].  I am shifting 2 percentage points from bottom to top bucket. Furthermore, today Farage made a campaign promise that may attract more votes: "If win on Thursday, we will kill off any chance of them forcing a second referendum on us, because they know they would lose." [2] Shifting another 3 points to the top bucket. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2019/may/21/brexit-latest-news-developments-cabinet-to-discuss-latest-brexit-offer-to-mps-as-ministers-feud-in-public-over-no-deal-live-news

I am expecting that they will still loose some pro Brexit votes to the UKIP party - but UKIP is increasingly marginalised and disorderly. Outside of disapproval of the main 2 parties, I see this as less of a serious political party and more of a well organised charismatic media campaign. They will pick up votes from discord and avoid any serious debate over their positions or lack of policies with adroitness. I expect the remain vote to be splintered. Turnout will be low which benefits antagonists as well.
Voters may well be disappointed with the way the politicians have handled the Brexit votes. Tjis may well be pay back time and I expect a massibe victory for the Brexit party.
Feel like the whole right wing thing isn’t over yet.

According to opinion polls, the Brexit Party is on track to win 34 per cent of European Parliament seats. It's possible that opponents of a no-deal Brexit may react by redoubling their efforts. It's equally possible that Brexit Party members may feel re-energized by the poll results and redouble their efforts.

Four days to go. An average of the 7 most recent polls weighted by sample size puts the Brexit Party on 33.4%. Latest polling figures; 34%, 27%, 35%*, 34%, 31%, 34%*, 30% * Large sample size The gap between the margin of victory forecast by YouGov and the other pollsters has roughly halved. The difference between what the pollsters forecast for each party in 2014 and the actual result; 1.5% UKIP
1.0% Labour
2.0% Conservative
1.5% LibDem
1.5% Others Crowd: 8%, 18%, 28%, 33%, 13%

Raising the distribution. As I am weighing the latest Yougov poll slightly more heavily. Yougov has a B rating at 538. Moreover, UK polls have been shown to consistently underestimate Conservative chances. Though there is no guarantee this will continue, it leads me to raise the chances slightly. See here for sources: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/864558

I believe the original vote to come out of the EU was carried by average working people. They recognised there would be both negative and positive consequences from staying in or coming out and they elected to come out. They will do so again as the rationale behind their decision has not changed. They do not trust any of the incumbent politicians to deliver their democratic mandate. That said the vote for the Brexit party will be tempered by voters in Scotland, Northern Ireland, London and the mid-east.

At the present time; Saturday 18th May 2019, I think there is a 40% chance the Brexit Party will achieve between 25-30% of the total votes cast. The basis of this belief been there is dissatisfaction with the Conservative Party (principally via their handling of the Brexit process). The EU vote also allows for voter expression on what will likely be a single issue vote (ie Brexit), rather than voters consideration of governmental policy (in which the Brexit Party would likely receive less than 5% of the vote).  Additionally, Labour are not offering any viable policy difference to the Conservatives, and have themselves likely become perceptively muddied in their handling of the Brexit process as opposition to the Conservatives. Recent results from UK local elections also indicate wholesale dissatisfaction with the Conservatives & Labour parties.
People are stupid and still believe Farage and Johnson.
Disappointed with the other parties to deliver Brexit. Party has one clear simple message. Also a proxy referendum on EU
Because people want easy answers not complexity.

Six days to go. The pollsters are very divided [1] with regard to the Brexit Party. The last few polls from each company are; • YouGov: 28%, 30%, 34%, 35%
• ComRes: 17%, 28%, 27%, 27%
• Opinium: 12%, 28%, 29%, 34%
• Survation: 27%, 30% An average weighted by date and poll size currently puts them on 32.5%. The latest survey by YouGov [2] has Labour on 15% (split 3-1 remain-leave) and the Tories on just 9% (split 1-1 remain-leave) so there simply aren't many more leave voters left to switch to the Brexit Party, however they are only 2.5% from the 35% threshold so they could  just sneak into that top bucket. Indeed if YouGov are correct, the Brexit Party are in the top bucket already and the crowd has got this one wrong. Crowd: 14%, 19%, 28%, 26%, 13% [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls
[2] https://yougov.co.uk/topics/politics/articles-reports/2019/05/17/labour-and-tories-lose-majority-support-brexit-pro
The polls keep swinging towards this eventuality.

Current polls already show a strong lead for the Brexit party. Given that neither the conservatives nor Labour  seem to have a clear goal behind their campaigns the Brexit party is likely to gain further ground in the days before the EP election.

I reckon they'll do slightly less well than they are currently polling, as happened in 2014, and that they will be constrained by a high turnout. But then, I'm an optimist. I admit what I predict is very heavily clouded by what I hope for this one!
It's likely they'll draw some people, but many will probably spoil their ballot. Though their name is simple so attractive to those pro-brexit
They have nothing to contribute to the talks
Farage looks agitated and not relaxed. New revelations about him and Russian links could surface and spoil his chances of greater gains.

Because the same fools who voted in favor of Brexit have a mindset similar to
Trump supporters. I’m guessing that They’re going to stick with their initial impulse and will back their first choice, no matter what negative information surfaces against brexit
Based on other forecasts and crowd forecasting
Brexit has lost a lot of popularity recently, and most people seemed to think that the middle option was the best. (between 25% and 30%)
I've done the same as anyone else , and followed the same algorithim.
Massive protest vote from leavers is likely and polling is showing this
Mood of the country with current state of brexit
Polls probably overestimate support on the day

UPD1: Judging by polls above 25% is more likely now Well in 2014 European elections UKIP won 13 seats and got 26% of popular vote. It is likely to have similar support although recent local election may indicate some minor disenchantment with UKIP. So lower 20 % is probably a good guess. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom

Weighted average of recent polls shows the Brexit Party smack dab in the middle of 25-30 bin [1]. While simple averaging of recent polls shows >35% [2], it is important to weigh polls by how recent and how large their sample is, which is what [1] does. [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-48227459
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom

The average of the five polls published in May is just over 35%. Two are at 34%, the other three between 27 and 29% https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom

Accounting for new information: FT poll of polls from May 9 shows 29% and 3% for UKIP. [1] Also in the FT story "surveys for the British Election Study /.../ indicated that the number of so called UKIP interested voters is in the high thirties" An important factor will be whether UKIP votes get transferred to the Brexit Party on Election Day, which is my assumption.  What could change my view: it will be important to consider how large the polling margin of error is. I am assuming it is no more than 5 percentage points (for the 95% interval).  The <25 bin: I don't see strong arguments why the polls should overestimate Brexit Party's chances by more than 5% points. If anything aren't voters often shy about proclaiming support for populists?  [1] https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjynezVjpfiAhWJT98KHXlgAzQQFjAAegQIARAB&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcontent%2F63295436-7277-11e9-bf5c-6eeb837566c5&usg=AOvVaw2eOzau3xs5TwjwOxtdQmko
34% is bonkers! Thanks T May for ruining Tories! https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/may/11/poll-surge-for-farage-panic-conservatives-and-labour

Adjusting in response to new polls and taking into account difference between the the polls before the 2014 EU elections  and the actual result, where Farage's previous party got  15% to 20% less votes than the polls were suggesting (if replicated this time would put the Brexit party at around 30% to 33%.)

27% 9 May We the plebs have only our vote. We are angry and indignant that our vote is being ignored. This is now about something more important than just leaving the EU - it's about democracy. The passion and emotion at Farage's rallies is something to behold. If you haven't seen any raw video of a Brexit Party rally, watch some before you make a forecast. Twelve days to go. Crowd: 10,22,37,21,10 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_LcPkRilbXY&t=45m19s

I am updating in the light of a new poll and by comparing polls before the 2014 election. 
In 2014 in the last few days of the campaign UKIP (then the leading pro-Brexit/protest party lead by Nigel Farage) dropped back about 4%. The Brexit Party is now the Nigel Farage Party and that seems to be polling slightly below the level that UKIP was in 2014. There so far seems to little sign of the residual  4% of UKIP supporter switching to Brexit. So my guess is that 2% or so of the UKIP support which switch to Brexit, but either 3% or so of Brexit Party voters will not turn out or they will switch (back) to the Conservatives. So at this stage unless anything dramatic happens my guess is that the final Brexit percentage will be close to what it is today (29%).
Its also interesting that for all the talk of Labour supporters changing their support to other parties their percentage support today is only 2% down on the 2014 result. The bigger shift that has taken place is that the Conservatives are down about 10%, while the several Leave supporting parties have picked up about 8% to 10% compared to 2014. 
The UK local elections seem to have had the effect of reminding Remain voters that even under the D'Hondt system a vote for a party that is under 10% (in any Region) could end up with no seats.

Based on polls [1] and comments by @Tetbury that Conservatives votes may move to the Brexit party [2] My forecast is based on the presumption that voters will use this opportunity to voice their view on Brexit rather than vote for the party they'd typically support. Edit: also worth keeping an eye on: https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5461/Which-UK-party-will-win-the-most-seats-in-the-2019-EU-election [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls HT @nigster
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/859113

New parties are a tricky problem for pollsters because they usually rely heavily on the results of previous elections, so this EU election is particularly difficult for them because there are two completely new parties; the Brexit Party and Change UK / The Independent Group / Remain Alliance / whatever they are calling themselves this week. Crowd: 11,23,35,18,13 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_European_Parliament_election_in_the_United_Kingdom#Opinion_polls
Approximately same as UKIP in last euro, more remainders will be motivated to turn out.
Based on polling, but with room on the upside. They may take a larger proportion of the UKIP vote as UKIP candidates alienate Leavers who find their views unpalatable

This party became the front-runner as soon as Farage established it. I think he has the strong backing of the leave voters, who generally view the conservatives as betraying the referendum. I will need to see more polling this month but right now the party is hovering right around 30%.

I can’t figure out UK. I suspect another referendum would result in “stay”. However I do believe (align with polls) brexit party will take most votes in EU elections. Brits do like their irony!
https://moneymaven.io/mishtalk/economics/brexit-party-soars-in-european-parliament-polls-9-points-ahead-of-labour-2RP43j7w7Uq84iYxIXde3g/ https://www.politico.eu/2019-european-elections/united-kingdom/

The polls have them on between 28% and 30%.  With Farage's former party UKIP on 4%. As under the D'Hondt voting system and the UKs Regional List system for EU elections 4% would not get any seats I would expect between now and 23rd May most of UKIP voters will move to The Brexit Party. 
Many Conservatives say they will switch to The Brexit Party for this election. I assume this is reflected in the polling.
If the Conservatives and Labour parties become clearer on what their Brexit position is between now and the 23rd, the voting share for the party would change a lot. e.g. If the Conservative and Labour agree to a Brexit Future Trade Agreement both parties would lose Remainer votes to the LibDems and ChangeUK, and Leave votes to the Brexit Party. For this reason think both Conservativea and Labour will avoid reaching any agreement before the 23rd. Its quite likely that the Conservative vote will shrink below the 13% predicted in the polls.
So I would forecast that support in the polls for The Brexit Party to rise to over 35% between now and 23rd, but will fall back to between 30% and 35% at the actual vote
This election is only considered a protest vote for Leave and Remain, so few people with be concerned about voting with the party that they would normally support in a National Election. Either they will not bother to vote or vote according their view on Remain or Leave the EU.

Right wing politicians are on the rise around the world, but the opposition has already rose against them. I believe they will have a significant voting, but it will not challenge the stablished parties.
The Brexit Party is polling in the high 20s, and the results for the Conservatives in the local elections were dreadful.
60% chances that Brexit party will be around 20-30%. Based on history of UKIP and the fact that this is the approximate number of protest leave voters.

Well in 2014 European elections UKIP won 13 seats and got 26% of popular vote. It is likely to have similar support although recent local election may indicate some minor disenchantment with UKIP. So lower 20 % is probably a good guess.
